issues.description: The template repository declares addGuestStudents with the signature addGuestStudents(int numberOfNewGuestStudents, boolean validateInput), while the problem statement and UML specify addGuestStudents(int): void and the solution implements addGuestStudents(int). This parameter mismatch is likely unintentional and will confuse students about which method to implement and may cause tests or automatic graders expecting the single-argument method to fail or be ambiguous.
issues.suggested_fix: Change the template method signature to match the specification and solution by providing a single-parameter stub: public void addGuestStudents(int numberOfNewGuestStudents) { /* TODO: implement */ }. If input validation is desired, either implement it inside that single-argument method or provide an additional overloaded private/internal method that accepts a boolean, but ensure the public API matches the problem statement (addGuestStudents(int)).

issues.description: The problem statement and the reference solution define an addGuestStudents method with a single int parameter (addGuestStudents(int)) but the template repository declares a stub with a different signature that includes an extra boolean parameter (addGuestStudents(int numberOfNewGuestStudents, boolean validateInput)). This mismatch means students looking at the template will not find the method signature described in the task/UML and may be confused about which method to implement (and can cause compilation or test-signature mismatches).
issues.suggested_fix: Update the template method signature to match the problem statement and solution: change the stub to public void addGuestStudents(int numberOfNewGuestStudents) and implement any input validation internally (remove the extra boolean parameter). This aligns the template with the UML/task and avoids student confusion or test/compilation issues.
